description.0:
The Atlas Farnese sculpture which is part of the collection of the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli has been found at Rome. It is made out of marble and is regarded as a 2nd cent. CE roman copy of an older greek statue. Large parts of the sculpture as it is presented today are the result of restauration work that had been carried out after its retrieval. 

Despite of being an artistic depiction of one of the mythological titans, the sculpture has been the topic of a very vivid discussion in the field of history of ancient astronomy especially in the last decades. The controversy centers around the celestial sphere that symbolizes the Sky that rests on the titan's shoulders. Should we regard the missing intersection of the ecliptic with the crossing of the celestial equator and one of the colure circles as the oldest visualisation of the effects of precession? Moreover, is it possible to show a direct connection of the constellations that are depicted on the sphere to the star catalogue of the greek astronomer Hipparchus (2nd cent. BCE) as it is argued by B. Shaefer in his computational evaluation from 2005? 

For further research, digital fotos of the Atlas Farnese sculpture have been made as data basis for the generation of the 3d model of the sculpture in BAAP-2. A selection of those fotos forms this digital ressource.
description.1:
The Atlas Farnese sculpture which is part of the collection of the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli has been found at Rome. It is made out of marble and is regarded as a 2nd cent. CE roman copy of an older greek statue. Large parts of the sculpture as it is presented today are the result of restauration work that had been carried out after its retrieval. 

Despite of being an artistic depiction of one of the mythological titans, the sculpture has been the topic of a very vivid discussion in the field of history of ancient astronomy especially in the last decades. The controversy centers around the celestial sphere that symbolizes the Sky that rests on the titan's shoulders. Should we regard the missing intersection of the ecliptic with the crossing of the celestial equator and one of the colure circles as the oldest visualisation of the effects of precession? Moreover, is it possible to show a direct connection of the constellations that are depicted on the sphere to the star catalogue of the greek astronomer Hipparchus (2nd cent. BCE) as it is argued by B. Shaefer in his computational evaluation from 2005? 

Based on digital fotos of whom a large part is accessible in BAAP-1, a 3d model of the complete Atlas Farnese at the Museo Archaeologico Nazionale at Naples has been generated. The scaling has been established on the basis of the measurement of a scale at the base of the sculpture. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d-model have been choosen arbitraryly.
description.2:
The Atlas Farnese sculpture which is part of the collection of the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli has been found at Rome. It is made out of marble and is regarded as a 2nd cent. CE roman copy of an older greek statue. Large parts of the sculpture as it is presented today are the result of restauration work that had been carried out after its retrieval. 

Despite of being an artistic depiction of one of the mythological titans, the sculpture has been the topic of a very vivid discussion in the field of history of ancient astronomy especially in the last decades. The controversy centers around the celestial sphere that symbolizes the Sky that rests on the titan's shoulders. Should we regard the missing intersection of the ecliptic with the crossing of the celestial equator and one of the colure circles as the oldest visualisation of the effects of precession? Moreover, is it possible to show a direct connection of the constellations that are depicted on the sphere to the star catalogue of the greek astronomer Hipparchus (2nd cent. BCE) as it is argued by B. Shaefer in his computational evaluation from 2005? 

The depiction of the celestial sphere has been generated on the basis of a selection of fotos of whom a large part is accessible in BAAP-1. The coordinate system has been choosen according to the standard interpretation of the lines that represent the circles of the sky: the origin and the directions of the axes are choosen such that (1) the z-plane goes through the circle that represents the celestial equator and (2) the northern hemisphere of the globe lies in the halfspace with z > 0, (3) the x-axis points into the direction of the intersection of the representation of the celestial equator and the circle that represents the colure circle through the solsticial points with the positive branch of the x-axis pointing to the intersection that lies on the summer part of the colure circle, and (4) the y-axis points into the direction of the intersection of the representation of the celestial equator and the circle that represents the colure circle through the equinoxes with the positive branch of the y-axis pointing to the intersection that lies on the vernal part of the colure circle.
description.3:
The Atlas Farnese sculpture which is part of the collection of the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli has been found at Rome. It is made out of marble and is regarded as a 2nd cent. CE roman copy of an older greek statue. Large parts of the sculpture as it is presented today are the result of restauration work that had been carried out after its retrieval. 

Despite of being an artistic depiction of one of the mythological titans, the sculpture has been the topic of a very vivid discussion in the field of history of ancient astronomy especially in the last decades. The controversy centers around the celestial sphere that symbolizes the Sky that rests on the titan's shoulders. Should we regard the missing intersection of the ecliptic with the crossing of the celestial equator and one of the colure circles as the oldest visualisation of the effects of precession? Moreover, is it possible to show a direct connection of the constellations that are depicted on the sphere to the star catalogue of the greek astronomer Hipparchus (2nd cent. BCE) as it is argued by B. Shaefer in his computational evaluation from 2005? 

On the celestial sphere, several circular lines represent the circles of the sky such as equator, ecliptic, tropic circles, and colure circles. Their areas as well as those parts of the 3d model that belong to the sphere itself have been selected from the 3d model of the celestial sphere and made accessible for further evaluation in separate files. All point selections are based on the reduced model of BAAP-3 and use the same coordinate system.
description.4:
The Atlas Farnese sculpture which is part of the collection of the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli has been found at Rome. It is made out of marble and is regarded as a 2nd cent. CE roman copy of an older greek statue. Large parts of the sculpture as it is presented today are the result of restauration work that had been carried out after its retrieval. 

Despite of being an artistic depiction of one of the mythological titans, the sculpture has been the topic of a very vivid discussion in the field of history of ancient astronomy especially in the last decades. The controversy centers around the celestial sphere that symbolizes the Sky that rests on the titan's shoulders. Should we regard the missing intersection of the ecliptic with the crossing of the celestial equator and one of the colure circles as the oldest visualisation of the effects of precession? Moreover, is it possible to show a direct connection of the constellations that are depicted on the sphere to the star catalogue of the greek astronomer Hipparchus (2nd cent. BCE) as it is argued by B. Shaefer in his computational evaluation from 2005? 

Several graphical representations of the celestial sphere in cylindrical and in stereographic projection from the north and south pole show the outlines of the constellations and lines that are depicted on the celestial sphere of the Atlas Farnese sculpture. The contours of the figures and lines are established by representing each vertex of the 3d-model with edges that are inclined towards each other in an angle > 8.5° by an black dot. In the diagrams, the abscissas correspond to the azimuth values in respect to the x-axis in the 3d model and the direction of the z-axis corresponding to the pole, and the ordinates correspond to the elevations of the points towards the equator.
description.5:
Since 2000, a plaster cast of the celestial globe of the Atlas Farnese sculpture from the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli is part of the collection of the Abguss-Sammlund Antiker Plastik of the Freie Universität Berlin (Inv. no. 4/00). 

Digital fotos of the cast have been made as data basis for the generation of the 3d model in BAAP-7.
description.6:
"Since 2000, a plaster cast of the celestial globe of the Atlas Farnese sculpture from the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli is part of the collection of the Abguss-Sammlund Antiker Plastik of the Freie Universität Berlin (Inv. no. 4/00). 

Based on the digital fotos of BAAP-6, a 3d model of the cast has been generated. Scaling, position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system are choosen arbitraryly."
description.7:
A fragment of a celestial globe is part of the Antikensammlung der Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz (Ident.no. SK 1050 a). The fragment dates from the 1st cent. CE. and origins from Rome. It is made out of blue marble. Originally, it had been decorated with inlays of which 13 yellow stones have been preserved. 

On the outer surface of a sphere, 16 small circular shaped holes in which 13 yellow stones still are preserved and the contours of five figures that represent stars and constellations can be identified. From left to right we see with the heads oriented to the lower parts of the fragment: (1) arm and leg of the Kneeling Man/Engonasin, (2) Lyra, (3) Cygnus or the Bird, (4) Kassiopeia, and (5) a small portion of one of the forehoofs of Pegasus or the Horse. The surface of the preserved part of the fragment coincides precisely with a sphere. In addition, the circular line that runs through the figure of the Kneeling Man at the left edge of the fragment is a great circle on that sphere and stands in right angle to the circular line at the lower edge of the fragment.  Accordingly, the circular lines can be identified as the tropic circle at the lower edge of the fragment, and a Colure Circle that runs through the figure of the Kneeling Man at the left edge of the fragment. The great circle that passes Lyra and runs through Cygnus and Cassiopeia can be identified as the Milky Way. 

In the 3d-model, the center of the sphere has been choosen as the origin of the coordinate system. The axes have been choosen such that (1) the (positive) x-axis goes through the intersection of the semicircle of the colure circle through the figure of the Kneeling Man with the reconstructed celestial equator (a great circle that is parallel to the circular line at the lower edge of the fragment), (2) the z-plane is parallel to the tropic circle at the lower edge of the fragment, and (3) the fragment lies in the halfspace with z > 0. The 3d-model is devided into two parts that contain the outer and inner surfaces of the fragment in separate files. All 3d-models have been generated by using a calibrated scanner.
description.8:
A fragment of a celestial globe is part of the Antikensammlung der Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz (Ident.no. SK 1050 a). The fragment dates from the 1st cent. CE. and origins from Rome. It is made out of blue marble. Originally, it had been decorated with inlays of which 13 yellow stones have been preserved. 

The fragment shows the figures of five constellations, 16 stars, and parts of several circular lines such as tropic circle, colure circle, and the Milky Way. Based on the 3d-model from BAAP-8 their contours have been extracted. Since the data given in the files use the same coordinate system as the 3d-model in DigRes 1, they are fully compatible with each other.
description.9:
"A fragment of a celestial globe is part of the Antikensammlung der Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz (Ident.no. SK 1050 a). The fragment dates from the 1st cent. CE. and origins from Rome. It is made out of blue marble. Originally, it had been decorated with inlays of which 13 yellow stones have been preserved. The fragment shows the figures of five constellations, 16 stars, and parts of several circular lines such as tropic circle, colure circle, and the Milky Way. 

The graphical representations of the 3d model of BAAP-8 in cylindrical projection show the contours of the figures, stars and lines by representing each vertex of the 3d-model with edges that are inclined towards each other in an angle > 8.5° (BAAP-10-1) and > 5° (BAAP-10-2) by an black dot. In the diagrams, the abscissas correspond to the azimuth values in respect to the x-axis in the 3d model and the direction of the z-axis corresponding to the pole, and the ordinates correspond to the elevations of the points towards the equator."
description.10:
"According to a description of C. Ptolemy (2nd cent. CE) in his Almagest (Ptol. Alm. VIII, 6), celestial globes were used as a means to derive information on celestial phenomena by manipulating the movable parts of the instrument according to a suitable procedure. Otherwise, these information would have been the result of very laborious and time-consuming calculations. 

In order to illustrate the basic principle of such procedures, the rotation of a celestial globe has been animated in a short film sequence. It shows a celestial globe with its axis inclined to the horizon of a given latitude. The position of the sun on the ecliptic circle that is marked by a yellow dot defines the date of the situation at display. The outlines of the fragment of a celestial globe from the Antikensammlung der Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz (Ident.no. SK 1050 a) have been included to indicate the depictions of figures of constellations and circular lines that have been reported as essential parts of ancient Greek and Roman celestial globes by ancient authors."
description.11:
The representations of positions of stars and constellations in textual sources vary considerably. For example, a large part of Aratus’ Phaenomena consists - sign by sign - in an enumeration of constellations (or their parts) that rise or set together with the rising of each of the 12 signs of the zodiac at a given latitude. 

The information can be used to derive new information about the spatial distribution of the constellations and their parts on the sky. The result has been visualized in a diagram. Each white line that runs from the top left to the bottom right can be considered as the western semicircle of the horizon at the time of the beginning of the rising of the sign of the zodiac written to the right of the lower end of the horizon line – or the western semicircle of the horizon at the time of the end of the rising of the sign of the zodiac written to the left of the lower end of the horizon line respectively. The white lines that run from the top right to the bottom left can, on the other hand, be considered as the eastern semicircle of the horizon at the time of the beginning of the rising of the sign of the zodiac written to the right of the lower end of the horizon line – or the eastern semicircle of the horizon at the time of the end of the rising of the sign of the zodiac written to the left of the lower end of the horizon line respectively. The numbers written on the gray shapes of the constellation refer to their names: 1 – Bootes; 2 – Crown; 3 – Ophiuchus; 4 – Serpent; 5 - Kneeling Man; 6 – Lyre; 7 – Cepheus; 8 – Eagle; 9 – Bird; 10 – Arrow; 11 – Dolphin; 12 – Horse; 13 – Cassiopeia; 14 – Andromeda; 15 – Perseus; 16 – Charioteer; 17 – Beast; 18 – Fish; 19 – River; 20 – Orion; 21 – Hare; 22 - Great Dog; 23 – Procyon; 24 – Argo; 25 – Hydra; 26 - Centaur + Beast; 27 – Altar.
description.12:
The representations of positions of stars and constellations in textual sources vary considerably. For example, texts describe the positions of constellations relative to each other, a form of data that Aratus used in his Phaenomena. 

These information has been visualized in a diagram. The positions and shapes of the gray areas that signify the constellations are based on the constellation’s position and extension on the sky. The black lines that connect constellations or parts of constellations stand for a relation between both constellations as described by Aratus.
description.13:
The representations of positions of stars and constellations in textual sources vary considerably. In his Commentary on the Phaenomena of Aratus and Eudoxus, Hipparchus recapitulates Eudoxus’ description of the positions of parts of the constellations relative to the polar, tropical and equatorial circles as well as two colure circles that run through the two poles and the intersections of the ecliptic with the equator and the two tropical circles. 

These information has been visualized in a diagram. Only the positions of the five constellations surrounded by circles in the diagram are fixed by this description. For all the other constellations that touch the circles, only the ordering along the circle is given.
description.14:
A number of literary texts and stone inscriptions have come down to us from the second century BCE onwards that list, for the period of an arbitrary solar year, certain astronomical events, such as the heliacal risings and settings of fixed stars, and the visibility of constellations, correlated with meteorological phenomena. 

The information contained in C. Ptolemy’s Phaseis from the 2nd cent. CE and in the so-called Geminus Parapegma has been analyzed and collected in a database in json format. In addition, a classification of the meteorological events is provided. For further information on the organization of the data a documentation can be accessed.
description.15:
A number of literary texts and stone inscriptions have come down to us from the second century BCE onwards that list, for the period of an arbitrary solar year, certain astronomical events, such as the heliacal risings and settings of fixed stars, and the visibility of constellations, correlated with meteorological phenomena. Especially the parapegma text in C. Ptolemy’s Phaseis from the 2nd cent. CE shows a very rich variety of meteorological events. Ptolemy himself did not add any new weather information to his text. Instead, any information is justified by a reference to one of his 12 authorities. 

Based on the Phaseis and the classification of the meteorological events as presented in the database of BAAP-15 the frequency of the occurrence of different types of meteorological events for each authority have been visualized.
description.16:
A number of literary texts and stone inscriptions have come down to us from the second century BCE onwards that list, for the period of an arbitrary solar year, certain astronomical events, such as the heliacal risings and settings of fixed stars, and the visibility of constellations, correlated with meteorological phenomena. Especially the parapegma text in C. Ptolemy’s Phaseis from the 2nd cent. CE shows a very rich variety of meteorological events. Ptolemy himself did not add any new weather information to his text. Instead, any information is justified by a reference to one of his 12 authorities. 

Based on the Phaseis and the classification of the meteorological events as presented in the database of BAAP-15 the occurrence of different types of meteorological events during the year for each authority can be visualized in an interactive applet. The applet uses Wolfram Mathematica and can be accessed by this software of by means of the Wolfram Mathematica cdf Player.
description.17:
"A number of literary texts and stone inscriptions have come down to us from the second century BCE onwards that list, for the period of an arbitrary solar year, certain astronomical events, such as the heliacal risings and settings of fixed stars, and the visibility of constellations, correlated with meteorological phenomena. In his Phaseis from the 2nd cent. CE C. Ptolemy did not add any new weather information to his text. Instead, he fully relies on 12 authorities. As he describes in the text that accompanies the parapegma, he unveils an additional meaning of those names: All persons claimed their findings only for a small number of countries or regions. According to Ptolemy, their validity is also given for other places that belong to the same climate. 

In the interactive applet it can be visualized, for which regions and climates Ptolemy claims the validity of the information of each authority. The applet uses Wolfram Mathematica and can be accessed by this software of by means of the Wolfram Mathematica cdf Player."
description.18:
"Next to the Apollon Temple at Pompei, a sundial that had been found in this area has been re-erected on the top of a column. Since the gnomon of the sundial is still preserved, this gives the possibility to observe the movement of the shadow during a longer period of time. The trace of the shadow of the tip of the gnomon shows very clearly that in this case the sundial is mispossitioned with regard to the meridian. 

The film has been generated by combining fotos from the same perspective to a movie. The fotos have been taken on September 16th in 2013 between 1:36 pm and 4:34 pm UTC+2 with a time-lag of 30secs."
description.19: Digital fotos of a miniature Sundial with vertical dialface that has been found in Egypt. Possibly, the sundial dates from the 2nd half of the 1st millennium BCE. It is made from alabaster.
description.20:
The dark green shadow clock with white inscriptions and markings which is part of the collection of the Ägyptisches Museum und Papyrussammlung of the Staatliche Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz (Ident.no. ÄM 19743) has probably been found at Fayum/Egypt. It is datet to the Late Period. The object is made out of graywacke. 

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly.
description.21:
"The egyptian shadow board  (Ident.no. ÄM 14084) and the sighting instrument (Ident.no. ÄM 14085) from BAAP-24 were bought together in Cairo. Probably, both astronomical instruments were found at Abydos. Today, they are part of the collection of the Ägyptisches Museum und Papyrussammlung of the Staatliche Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz. The shadow board is made from ivory and dates from about 600 BCE. The shape of the object resembles an egyptian shadow clock. An inscription on the bottom side refers to the astronomical context of the instrument. 

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly."
description.22:
"The egyptian sighting instrument (Ident.no. ÄM 14085) and the shadow board (Ident.no. ÄM 14084) from BAAP-23 were bought together in Cairo/Egypt. Probably, both astronomical instruments were found at Abydos/Egypt. Today, they are part of the collection of the Ägyptisches Museum und Papyrussammlung of the Staatliche Museen zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz. The sighting instrument is made out of palm leaf. An inscription refers to the astronomical context of the instrument. 

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly."
description.23:
Digital fotos/3d model of a portable sundial that has been found in Herculaneum. The sundial dates from the time between 27 BCE and 79 CE. It is made from bronze. Due to its characteristic shape, this sundial is known as the Prosciutto di Ercolaneo (Ham from Herculaneum) 

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly.
description.24:
"Digital fotos/3d model of a portable sundial that has been found at the river shores close to the Römerbrücke at Trier. The sundial is made from bronze.

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly."
description.25:
Digital fotos/3d model of a portable Sundial that has been found at Aphrodisias. The sundial dates from not earlier than the foundation of Constantinople. It is made from bronze.

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly.
description.26:
"Digital fotos/3d model of a portable Sundial that comes from unknown provenance, probably from Samos. The sundial dates from not earlier than the foundation of Constantinople. It is made from bronze.

The 3d model has been generated by using a calibrated scanner. The position of the origin and the orientation of the axes of the coordinate system of the 3d model have been choosen arbitraryly."
